DOC.HEAD: Christmas Cheer Scarce in Ravaged Neighborhood
Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Glad tidings and signs of peace on Earth are scant among the bullet- and rocket-pocked facades of the humble homes of Conacaste. The family of Elpidio Verdugo set up a 3-foot artificial Christmas tree and draped it with a string of tiny lights that hardly ever twinkle because the electricity is on only a couple hours a day. There are no presents beneath the tree and Verdugo's wife, Gloria, doubts there will be. ``The country is in mourning,'' Verdugo said. The 45-year-old bank teller, his wife and their four teenage children spent the better part of three days last month huddled beneath mattresses draped over tables in the kitchen-living room of their cinderblock house. Outside, the crack of fire from assault rifles and machine-guns filled Alley 6. An acrid gauze of gunsmoke reduced visibility to 15 feet, streamed through the shattered windows and seeped through cracks where the mattresses overlapped, stinging eyes and giving the terrified family even more reason to cry. The Verdugos' neighborhood of Conacaste in Soyapango, just east of San Salvador, was the most devastated of several working-class districts ravaged by fierce combat last month in and around the nation's capital. A guerrilla offensive launched Nov. 11 killed up to 2,000 people and was the biggest push of a 10-year-old civil war between leftist rebels and a succession of U.S.-backed governments. The Verdugos finally were able to evacuate by climbing over the rear wall on Nov. 15. They returned after a week of refuge at the nearby psychiatric hospital to find their home a shambles. The roof of the bedroom of 16-year-old son, Stanley, was blown to bits by either a rocket-propelled grenade or a rocket fired by a helicopter. A crater surrounded by a whorl of black marks the point of impact on the white wall. The corrugated synthetic tile roofing sheet has been replaced with cardboard, the same material covering Stanley's bedsprings. ``The mattresses were burned up or torn to shreds,'' said Mrs. Verdugo. The yellow refrigerator has a bullet hole in the side, patched with cloth and tape so the refrigerant doesn't leak. Two kitchen chairs sprout foam rubber stuffing where bullets ripped through them. Verdugo estimated the damage at about $600, six months of his salary. The family has no savings. Officials of a government housing fund visited to evaluate damage. They promised money to help reconstruct. ``But they also promised help to repair damages from the (1986) earthquake, and that never came,'' said the father. ``We'll do what we can to celebrate the arrival of the Christ child,'' said Mrs. Verdugo. She plans to prepare turkey or chicken, pastries and homemade candies for visits of friends and relatives on Christmas Eve and Christmas Day. ``Even amid so much poverty, there's always the joy of Christmas. We've always got faith, and the hope that this won't happen again,'' she said. Xiomara, the 13-year-old daughter, said she had been hoping to receive a new dress or some other gift at Christmas. ``But I understand why there won't be presents this year. And it doesn't matter, really.'' Mrs. Verdugo said she does not entertain illusions that the Christmas spirit of good will toward men might somehow foster peace. ``In a moment of anguish, like in the middle of the battle, people accept Christ in their heart. But then when things calm down, they forget. For there to be peace, Christ has to be in people's hearts all the time,'' she said.
